title: 108_s348
content: The Act titled "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" expands the deduction for higher education expenses. The Act "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" expands the deduction for higher education expenses, amending the limitations on the deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" expands the deduction for higher education expenses, with applicable taxable years of 2003 at $8,000 and 2004 onwards at $12,000. There is a limitation based on modified adjusted gross income for the deduction amount. The deduction for higher education expenses is subject to reduction based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with a threshold of $65,000 ($130,000 for joint filers). The deduction for higher education expenses is based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with thresholds of $65,000 for individuals and $130,000 for joint filers. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' is defined as the taxpayer's adjusted gross income for the taxable year, excluding specific sections, and after the application of certain provisions. Adjusted gross income for these sections should be determined without considering the deduction allowed under this section. Adjusted gross income for specific sections (86, 135, 137, 219, 221, and 469) should be determined without the deduction allowed under this section. Dollar amounts in subparagraph (B)(i)(II) will be increased for taxable years after 2003. For taxable years after 2003, dollar amounts in subparagraph (B)(i)(II) will be increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3) for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins. The taxable year begins by substituting `calendar year 2002' for `calendar year 1992' in subparagraph (B) thereof. If any adjusted amount is not a multiple of $50, it shall be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. Section 222(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended regarding the allowance of deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses of eligible students. Section 222(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow a deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses of eligible students. The definition of an eligible student is clarified in the amendment. The amendment redesignates paragraphs (2) through (6) as paragraphs (3) through (7) and adds a new definition for "eligible student." The deduction for qualified tuition expenses is made permanent, and the amendments apply to payments after December 31, 2002. SEC. 25C. INTEREST ON HIGHER EDUCATION LOANS. The tax code allows individuals to claim a credit for interest paid on qualified education loans, with a maximum credit of $1,500, subject to limitations based on modified adjusted gross income. The tax code allows individuals to claim a credit for interest paid on qualified education loans, with a maximum credit of $1,500. The credit amount is reduced if the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeds $50,000 ($100,000 for joint returns), with a reduction ratio based on income levels. The credit amount for interest paid on qualified education loans is reduced based on modified adjusted gross income, with a maximum credit of $1,500. The reduction ratio is determined by income levels exceeding $50,000 ($100,000 for joint returns). The $50,000 and $100,000 amounts for the education loan interest credit will be adjusted for inflation after 2003. The education loan interest credit amounts are adjusted for inflation after 2003. No credit is allowed if a deduction for the individual is claimed by another taxpayer in the same calendar year. Amounts adjusted under subparagraph (C) are rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. The credit under this section is limited to interest paid on a qualified education loan in the first 60 months. Refinancings are considered as one loan. The section defines a qualified education loan and a dependent for tax purposes. It also states that no double benefit can be claimed for the same deduction under any other tax provision. The section specifies rules for claiming the education credit, including denying double benefits, requiring married couples to file jointly, and determining marital status according to section 7703. The taxpayer and their spouse must file a joint return to claim the credit, with marital status determined according to section 7703. The amendments made by this section apply to any qualified education loan incurred on, before, or after the date of the enactment of this Act, but only with respect to any loan interest payment due after December 31, 2002.
